item.title: UK already undergoing disruptive climate change
item.description: Last year was the third warmest, fifth wettest and eight sunniest on record in the UK, scientists warn.

item.title: Hillsborough: Fan injured in stadium disaster dies 32 years later
item.description: Andrew Devine's family says the coroner's ruling confirms him as the 97th victim of the 1989 tragedy.

item.title: International cruises from England to restart
item.description: People arriving at UK ports who have been fully vaccinated in the US and the EU will not have to isolate.

item.title: Richer parents pressured teachers on exam grades
item.description: Sharp-elbowed parents have chased better grades in this year's replacement exams, a study says.

item.title: Outspoken billionaire Sun Dawu jailed for 18 years in China
item.description: Sun Dawu has in the past been vocal in criticising authorities and has spoken out about human rights.

item.title: Queen's lawyers secured amendment to Scottish green energy law
item.description: The legislation was changed so the monarch's private estates could not be subject to compulsory purchase orders.

item.title: Car production hit by 'pingdemic' and global chip shortage
item.description: The UK industry says the demand is there but it is "desperately trying to get back to full capacity".

item.title: Reckless to scrap BTecs, educators warn
item.description: The government is urged to rethink its plans to introduce new technical qualifications in England.

item.title: Covid: Furlough scheme set to wind down further
item.description: Employers will have to contribute more to the job support scheme before it is phased out in September.

item.title: Two women struck by lightning at Snowdon summit
item.description: Rescuers said the pair were "very lucky" to be alive after being hit by a lightning on Snowdon.

item.title: Google workers will need Covid jabs to return to office
item.description: The search engine says it will roll the policy out globally across its offices in the coming months.

item.title: Dusty Hill: ZZ Top bassist dies aged 72
item.description: Dusty Hill played bass for the iconic US blues rock band for more than five decades.

item.title: The Papers: Travel 'hope' and 'health risk' over quarantine end
item.description: The papers cover the impact of the decision to ease quarantine for vaccinated US and EU travellers.

item.title: Covid vaccines: Tourists head to the US to get vaccinated
item.description: Some tourists are spending thousands of dollars to travel to the US to get a coronavirus vaccine.

item.title: Mikey Poulli: The young blind footballer backed by star players
item.description: Mikey Poulli, who lost his sight due to a rare degenerative condition, dreams of playing for England.

item.title: Marble Arch Mound: 'I wouldn't pay £4 to walk up a hill'
item.description: The public reacts to London's newest tourist attraction, which is facing complaints of being incomplete.

item.title: Arthur: Popular children's show to end after 25 years
item.description: US public broadcaster PBS confirmed the final episode will air in winter 2022.

item.title: Aerial dancers enjoy striking Honister sunrise performance
item.description: Three aerial dancers suspend themselves from 1,000ft (305m) up for a routine in the Lake District.

item.title: Tidal turbine in Orkney starts generating power
item.description: The device, anchored in waters off Orkney, is now connected to the grid.

item.title: Covid: Medal for GP who came out of retirement to treat patients
item.description: A GP who came out of retirement to treat patients in the pandemic is awarded a medal.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: German gymnasts' full-body suits inspire other athletes
item.description: British-Jamaican gymnast Danusia Francis believes athletes should have a choice over their outfits.

item.title: Pingdemic: Bar staff being told to delete NHS app
item.description: One in five hospitality workers are isolating, and some are being told to delete the NHS Covid app.

item.title: H.E.R. on shedding her anonymity and conquering R&B
item.description: For years the singer stayed in the shadows but after Grammy and Oscar wins she's ready to be seen.

item.title: Gaza photographer hopes digital art boom can help raise aid money
item.description: A Palestinian photographer wants to help children by selling an image from May's conflict.

item.title: South Africa riots: The inside story of Durban's week of anarchy
item.description: The worst unrest since white-minority rule ended has left deep scars, especially in the coastal city of Durban.

item.title: Music industry turns to livestreaming to boost revenue
item.description: Festivals, DJs and musicians are all using new tech to entertain fans and make money during Covid.

item.title: My Money: 'I had forgotten how it all adds up'
item.description: Marketeer Toni says being able to socialise more and meet colleagues is pushing her spending higher.

item.title: Are middle-aged people more unhealthy than ever?
item.description: Why could the current cohort of 40-somethings be proving less healthy than previous generations?

item.title: Midtjylland dump Celtic out of Champions League
item.description: Beleaguered Celtic's Champions League hopes ended in the second qualifying round for the second consecutive year as a callow side were undone in extra time by Denmark's Midtjylland.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: USA's Caeleb Dressel breaks Olympics record to win 100m freestyle
item.description: Watch as USA swimmer Caeleb Dressel wins the 100m freestyle to claim his second gold at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: World champion pole vaulter Kendricks out of Games after positive Covid test
item.description: American pole vaulter Sam Kendricks is ruled out of the Tokyo Olympics after testing positive for coronavirus.

item.title: PSG open Pogba talks - Thursday's football gossip
item.description: PSG open Pogba discussions, Arsenal offer Bellerin in Martinez deal, Spurs targeting Vlahovic, plus more.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Team GB's Kye Whyte and Bethany Shriever reach BMX racing semi-finals
item.description: Watch as Team GB riders Kye Whyte and Bethany Shriever reach men's and women's BMX semi-finals at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Fintan McCarthy and Paul O'Donovan win Ireland's first Olympic rowing gold
item.description: Watch Finton McCarthy and Paul O'Donovan make history by winning Ireland's first Olympic rowing gold with victory in the men's lightweight double sculls.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Team GB's Duncan Scott wins 200m individual medley semi-final
item.description: Watch as Team GB's Duncan Scott swims his way into the 200m individual medley final where he will try to win his third medal at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Caeleb Dressel breaks Olympic record on way to second gold
item.description: USA's Caeleb Dressel sets an Olympic record on his way to winning the men's 100m freestyle gold as he aims to become one of the most successful swimmers at a Games.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Helen Glover rules out another Games bid
item.description: Britain's Helen Glover rules out another Olympics rowing bid after the mother of three's hopes of a fairytale finish at Tokyo 2020 are dashed.

item.title: What are the twisties in gymnastics?
item.description: US gymnast Simone Biles said she was "having a little bit of the twisties".

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: How to think like a champion
item.description: Newsbeat speaks to Bill Beswick, the psychologist behind the 26-year-old breaststroke star.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics rowing: Ireland's Paul O'Donovan & Fintan McCarthy win lightweight men's double sculls
item.description: Ireland win their first gold medal of the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games as Paul O'Donovan and Fintan McCarthy claim the lightweight men's double sculls.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Day-by-day guide to the key events, big stars and British medal hopes
item.description: Want to know what's happening when in Tokyo? Check out our comprehensive guide to all the action in Japan.

item.title: Why cannabis is still a banned Olympics substance
item.description: US sprinter Sha'carri Richardson won't compete due to a positive marijuana test. People are asking why.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Great Britain sevens plans 'a joke' - Dan Bibby
item.description: Great Britain sevens star Dan Bibby describes a planned future sevens programme as "a joke" after the team miss out on a medal in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Charlotte Dujardin wins dressage bronze to become most decorated female Briton
item.description: Great Britain's Charlotte Dujardin becomes Great Britain's most decorated female Olympian by winning dressage bronze at Tokyo 2020.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Why 'superhuman' Simone Biles could change attitudes to mental health in sport
item.description: Athletes discuss Simone Biles' decision to prioritise her mental health at the Tokyo Olympics and how she could change attitudes in sport.

item.title: From garden pool to Olympic gold
item.description: Matt Richards' relay swim team almost broke the world record as they won gold in Tokyo.

item.title: Murray and Salisbury out of men's doubles
item.description: Andy Murray's bid for an Olympic gold at a third successive Games ends as he and Joe Salisbury lose in the men's doubles semi-finals in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Great Britain win emphatic gold in 4x200m freestyle relay
item.description: Great Britain's men secure another gold in the Olympic pool with a dominant victory in the 4x200m freestyle relay in Tokyo.

item.title: Watch: 'There's going to be a crash!'
item.description: Team GB miss out on a medal in the men's four final after some dramatic steering issues almost cause a crash at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Ariarne Titmus claims second gold in women's 200m freestyle
item.description: Ariarne Titmus wins her latest battle with five-time Olympic gold medallist Katie Ledecky and sets a Games record in the women's 200m freestyle.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Great Britain women's hockey team sweep aside India and Germany beat Ireland
item.description: Great Britain women's hockey team continue the defence of their Olympic title with a convincing 4-1 win against India in pool A, while Germany beat Ireland.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Take a tour of the incredible venues
item.description: They range from an arena built by a father and son, to a legendary home of Japanese martial arts.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics medals table
item.description: Medals table for the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.

item.title: Coronavirus: Four numbers that reveal the real trends
item.description: Does a week of falling case numbers mean we're close to the end?

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid passports: How do they work around the world?
item.description: How are countries enforcing vaccine passports and what can people use them for?

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: All over-18s can now get the Covid jab, but the government has criticised take-up among young people.

item.title: Covid rules: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: People vaccinated in Europe or the US will no longer need to isolate when they arrive in England from an amber country.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate, which workers are exempt and what if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: A small number of named employees in key sectors will be exempt from some rules

item.title: 'Covid passports': How can the NHS Covid Pass prove I've had both jabs?
item.description: Clubbers and people attending mass events in England will have to prove they've had both Covid jabs.

item.title: Lockdown muscle loss: Five ways to get back in shape
item.description: Lockdown inactivity may have left people with weaker muscles - there are simple solutions.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: New research links as many as 200 different symptoms to the condition.

item.title: The EU vaccine 'passport' and what it means for travel
item.description: An EU vaccine "passport" is being introduced, enabling holders to prove they have been jabbed.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's adult population, as more than 46 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of children at higher risk from coronavirus infection will be offered a Covid vaccine in the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the NHS test-and-trace system and app work?
item.description: The contact tracing app could be changed to make it less sensitive, so it sends fewer alerts.

item.title: Care homes worst hit by Covid – search the data
item.description: Figures from Care Quality Commission lay out the pandemic's 'devastating impact' on care homes in England.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and how will Covid affect them?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics have begun, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid: Why is social distancing coming to an end?
item.description: Social distancing rules are changing across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Vaccine experts recommend that a limited group of children should be offered Covid jabs ahead of winter.

item.title: Beta coronavirus variant: What is the risk?
item.description: There are fears that this version of coronavirus, first identified in South Africa, is

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: As social distancing restrictions end in England and ease in Scotland, good ventilation remains vital.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.
